channel.title: Bitwise problem with configs

item.title: Bitwise problem with configs
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

;D[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:6, topic:521927”]I’m having a hard time on what tells the interface to be green and what tells it to be red.

You said that the only data being saved is the 2.
So you’re saying that in this: {1045, 49, 1, 2, 3}, the 2 is the only thing saved from what you edited?

I’m not seeing anywhere that saves 2 into the array.[/quote]
OFF

GREEN

RED

1 is RED, 2 is GREEN, 3 is OFF

I am looping through the array and storing them into the variable value at the same time.

When it hits the value GREEN, it will store the green value into the integer using a bitwise operator, and then it will (should) show the button as green.

The values are corresponding to the config value that activate the colors on the interface.

It’s basically like this but I’m shortening it by a lot in the method in my first post.

value |= (7 << 5);
value |= (7 << 8);
value |= (7 << 11);

This is what happens when I do that

As you can see, it only works once.

Maybe I would have to convert the values to look something like 0xFF or 0x22. I don’t know much about the byte values, so I wouldn’t know how to convert it.

Read full topic

item.title: Bitwise problem with configs
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

It seems like it is only storing the first value entered, which is 2. Can someone point out what I’ve done wrong?

{1045, 49, 1, 2, 3} = {ConfigId, ButtonId, valueRed, valueGreen, valuesOff}

public static final int[][] SETTINGS = {
	{1045, 49, 1, 2, 3},
	{1045, 55, 4, 5, 6}, 
	{1045, 52, 7, 8, 9}, 
	{1045, 51, 10, 11, 12}, 
	{1045, 54, 13, 14, 15}, 
	{1045, 53, 16, 17, 18}, 
	{1045, 66, 19, 20, 21}, 
	{1045, 65, 22, 24, 23}, 
	{1045, 61, 25, 26, 27}, 
	{1045, 62, 28, 29, 30}, 
	{1046, 56, 1, 2, 3},
	{1046, 64, 4, 4, 6}, 
	{1046, 50, 7, 8, 9}, 
	{1046, 57, 10, 11, 12}, 
	{1046, 58, 13, 14, 15}, 
	{1046, 59, 16, 17, 18}, 
	{1046, 63, 19, 20, 21}, 
	{1046, 68, 22, 24, 23}, 
	{1046, 67, 25, 26, 27}, 
	{1046, 60, 28, 29, 30}, 
	{1047, 69, 7, 8, 9},
	{1047, 70, 10, 11, 12},
	{1047, 71, 13, 14, 15},
	{1047, 72, 16, 17, 18},
	{1047, 73, 19, 20, 21},
	{1047, 74, 22, 23, 24},
	{1047, 75, 25, 26, 27},
	{1047, 76, 28, 29, 30},
	{1501, 79, 0, 1, 2},
};

private boolean[] hasBeenWarned = new boolean[SETTINGS.length];

public void sendInterface() {
	int value = 0;
	for (int i = 0; i < SETTINGS.length; ++i) {
		hasBeenWarned[i] = true;
	}
	for (int i = 0; i < SETTINGS.length; ++i) {
		if (hasBeenWarned[i]) {
			value |= (SETTINGS[i][0] & ~(7 << SETTINGS[i][3])) | (7 << SETTINGS[i][3]);
			ActionSender.sendConfig(player, SETTINGS[i][0], value);
		}
	}
	ActionSender.sendInterface(player, 583);
}

This is what happens when I use that. I already know the values are correct because I tested each of them separately.

All of them should be green.

Read full topic
